Southward *, R.J. Nash, C.T. O'Connor Catalysis Research Unit, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Cape Town, Private Bag, Rondebosch 7700, South Africa Received 9 June 1995; revised 11 August 1995; accepted 14 August 1995 Abstract An in-situ diffuse reflectance IR fourier transform spectroscopy study of the reduction/activation of Ga/H-ZSM-5 and variants thereof has been performed. These studies have shown a synergy between acidic supports (zeolitic and non-zeolitic) and Ga203, which leads to the reduction of the latter in either a H2 or propane stream, as evidenced by the loss in intensity of the uGa-O band. No reduction of Ga203 was observed when it was unsupported or supported upon non-acidic supports. In all cases the reduction process was accompanied by loss of BrOnsted acid groups due to reaction between the acidic site and gallium suboxide. Moreover, the appearance of a strong sharp band coincident with the known frequency of the ~,Ga-O band was also recorded and is presumed to indicate the presence of Ga20. Reduction of Ga/H-ZSM-5 using propane as a reductant was accom- panied by side reactions and coke deposition and appeared to be a less effective means of activating the catalyst. Keywords: Gallium; ZSM-5; Propane; DRIFTS; Aromatization 1. Introduction The transformation of lower alkanes into higher value compounds is a subject of current interest [ 1,2 ]. In particular the acid catalyzed dehydrocyclodimerization / aromatization of short chain linear alkanes into BTX (benzene, toluene and xylenes) has been widely reviewed [2-4] and studied [5-13]. The preferred catalysts for this process are based upon the MFI structure, and include H-ZSM-5 [9,14-16], Ga/H-ZSM-5 [7-13], Zn-ZSM-5 [16,17] and Pt/H-ZSM-5 [6,18]. * Corresponding author. Fax. However there are still unresolved questions concerning various aspects of the process. There is in particular, still uncertainty regarding the active site and reaction mechanism with bifunctional reaction [7,11-13,20], solid state reaction involving either Ga+Z- [6,8,21-23], (GaO) + [10,24,25] or Ga20 [26] species, or back- spillover mechanism [ 9,27 ], being proposed. Moreover, although it has been shown that pre-reduction or repeated reaction regeneration cycles leads to enhanced activ- ity and selectivity to BTX [ 3-8,12,13,21,27 ], it is still unclear what is the cause of these improvements or what is the nature of any activated gallium species formed [6,8,21-26]. In order to address these questions an in-situ diffuse reflectance IR fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) study of the reduction of various Ga-containing catalysts was performed. This paper presents data regarding the effects of support acidity, the choice of reductant and catalyst preparation method on the activation/ reduction of gallium-promoted aromatization catalysts. 2. The second unit in the apparatus was the gas delivery system in which the gas flow was regulated by two mass flow controllers enabling the dosing of small volumes of gas into the cell to monitor transient response or surface coverage and species with respect to dose. The third part of the apparatus is a Spectra-Tech high temperature/high pressure cell specially designed for in- situ studies. The cell is fitted with ZnSe windows and is rated to 900 (atmospheric pressure) and a maximum pressure of 10 MPa (at a maximum temperature of 600). The cell operates via downward flow which eliminated possible fluidization of the catalyst. The heated sample cup consisted of heater elements potted in alumina encased in a molybdenum shell. It was controlled using a 0-12 V variac unit in conjunction with a type K thermocouple controller, using zero crossing proportional output. The heater control unit also contained specific circuitry to compensate for varying heat loads to enable consistent temperatures to be achieved to an accuracy of better than I. At higher temperatures the cell windows are cooled by drawing distilled water (flow > 50 ml min ~ ) through the cooling coil by means of a vacuum aspirator. In all cases in-situ spectra were collected using a Nicolet 5ZDX FTIR spectrom- eter, operating in the DRIFTS mode, by co-addition of 250 scans at 4 cm- resolution. Hence all strong spectral bands below 2000 cm ~ manifest specular reflection effects, giving them a derivative shape. Ex-situ spectra were performed B. W.L. Difference spectra were generated by the mathematical subtraction of the reference spectra from the sample spectra. In-situ activation studies were performed by the incremental heating of the sample in flowing He (30 ml min-1) to 400 at which temperature the catalyst was pre-conditioned for 1 h. The flow was then switched to reductant (30 ml min-1), namely, H2 (5% in N2) or propane. The sample was then exposed to reductant for 15 min and the spectra recorded. The sample temperature was then raised, in the flowing reductant, and equilibrated for 15 min at 450 and the spectra taken. This process was repeated at 50 intervals up to and including 800. TPR analysis of the Ga203, GaBM and GalX was performed using apparatus designed in-house. 3. In-Situ DRIFTS of GaS1 at (a) 400 He, (b) 400 H2, (c) 450, (d) 500, (e) 550, (f) 600, (g) 650, (h) 700, (i) 750 and (j) 800. From these results it was apparent that, in the absence of the zeolite,/3-Ga203 did not undergo any significant degree of reduction. No loss in vGa-O band intensity was observed and the most significant spectral changes observed were due to lattice vibration, occurring at higher temperatures. This observation is con- sistent with TPR findings, which showed no reduction and with the reported liter- ature [6,8,26,29,30]. In the case of both GaBM and GaIX, significant spectral changes were observed. Both displayed a reduction of intensity in the Brsted acid uOH band (3610 cm-l), but not in the silanol vOH (3732 cm-1). The appearance of a strong sharp band or derivative shaped band at ca. 670 cm- ~ (a variation of + 8 cm- ~ was recorded over all spectra) was also observed (Fig. 4). This frequency correlates to the reported value of the vGa-O band [31 ]. The framework bands of the zeolite showed little change with respect to temperature, indicating the strong band phenomena was unlikely to be due to thermal agitation of the lattice or spectral noise. The appearance of bands at 3036 and 3146 cm-1 (vN-H bands) for GaIX was recorded, consistent with the reduction the nitrate precursor. Ex-situ transmission of GaBM (Fig. 8) showed a loss of the uGa-O band present prior to activation, indicating a loss of Ga203, in agreement with the findings of Kanazirev et al. [ 31 ]. In comparison, the spectra of H-ZSM-5 reflected only a loss of both Brcmsted acid and silanol groups (Fig. 7), with no change in the zeolite framework bands being recorded. B.W.L. The role of the support in the activation process was examined by attempting the in-situ reduction of GaS 1, GaSIL and GaSAL. These results are shown in Fig. 9, Fig. 10, Fig. 11 and Fig. 12. From these data it was evident that GaS 1 showed no significant degree of reduc- tion of the gallium. This was supported by post activation IR and inferred by the lack of the strong sharp band which appeared to be linked to the activation process. Some loss of silanol OH intensity was observed but this was ascribed to dehydrox- ylation rather than any reaction with the gallium. Similarly, GaSIL showed no significant spectral changes up to 650. Attempts to react samples of GaSIL at higher temperatures resulted in blocking of the porous tungsten frit of the cell, possibly by migration of SiO2. In all cases this led to a loss of flow through the cell and a pressure build up, forcing the curtailing of the experiment. Conversely, the activation of GaSAL was achieved, as evidenced ex-situ IR and by the appearance of the strong vGa-O band (again at ca. 670 cm- l), consistent with previous data. The occurrence of this sharp band was, however, both at higher temperatures and was of lower intensity than the analogous ZSM-5 case, possibly reflecting the different acidic properties of the two supports. The reduction of GaBM using propane (Fig. 13 and Fig. 14) showed similar phenomena to those displayed in the case of H2 reduction. Firstly there was a reduction in Br0nsted band intensity. This may indicate a weaker interaction/reaction between Ga203 and pro- pane than for Ga203 and H2. Coincident with reduction the conversion of the propane reductant was observed as one might expect. Spectral analysis of products formed was not possible due to the presence of gaseous and adsorbed propane which masked any contribution from reaction products. Coking of the catalyst and interior of the in-situ cell was also evident after completion of activation, with extensive carbonaceous deposition being recorded. 4. Discussion Previous studies concerning the activation of Ga203, Ga203/H-ZSM-5 have shown there is a 'low' temperature reduction in the latter case [6,8,13,21- 24,26,29,31,32]. This is supported by the spectral results obtained in this study and also by TPR analysis (Fig. 15 ) of Ga203, GaBM and GalX. The latter two samples exhibited reduction phenomena between 500 and 800 (the actual temperature of the ball mill sample depending upon milling time). Moreover, the data obtained indicate that the synergy observed is not merely due to the presence of the support, B.W.L. The major criteria for this synergy is the presence of BrCnsted acidity within the support, irrespective of whether the support is zeolitic or not. Hence GaBM, GaIX, GaBMP and GaSAL all exhibited gallium reduction phenomena, whereas Ga203, GaS 1 and GaSIL did not. However, it is clear that the interaction between H-ZSM-5 and Ga203 is the strongest, based upon the higher activation temperatures required for GaSAL. This may due to a more homogeneous BrCnsted acid site distribution and/or presence of stronger sites in the zeolite. The interaction of the oxide with the BrCnsted acid sites of the support is further evidenced by loss in intensity of the 3610 cm-~ band in all cases of reduction (Fig. 3, Fig. 6 and Fig. 14). The loss of BrCnsted acidity for GaBM, GaIX and GaBMP is confirmed by comparison with H-ZSM-5 which exhibited only minor dehydroxylation at comparative temperatures, leading to losses in both BrCnsted and silanol band intensity (Fig. 7). This is in agreement with the work of Price and Kanazirev [8] and Sphiro et al. [6] who observed similar losses in intensity for Ga/H-ZSM-5 and Pt promoted Ga/H-ZSM-5, respectively. This observation also supports the 'solid state reaction theory' of a mobile gallium moiety formed upon reduction of the bulk oxide [ 4,6,8,10,13,20-22,25,31 ]. The reaction of BrCnsted sites with gallium has been proposed to lead to the formation of new Lewis acid sites, without loss of total acidity [2,4,6,12,20,22]. Recent data supports this theory, based upon CO adsorption [22] and pyridine and H2 adsorption studies [6] all of which indicate the presence of strong electron 188 B. W.L. Alternatively, it has been suggested that in optimally active catalysts the gallium is present as a highly dispersed (GaO) + or Ga203 [ 10,25], with the role of the Ga+ being to facilitate the dispersion of the active Ga3 +. In these studies no characterization of the gallium post-activation was attempted, but it was clear that the gallium was not present as the bulk 3 + oxide (Fig. 8). However, in-situ results did show the presence of a species with an absorption band corresponding to the uGa-O. This sharp band phenomenon was present only in samples where reduction/activation of the gallium is observed. In all cases it was found to occur at the same frequency, irrespective of support, method of gallium addition or reductant. This indicates a common cause for the phenomenon, which is linked to the activation of the gallium. The coincidence of this adsorption band to the known frequency of uGa-O indicates the presence of Ga-O bonds consistent with the presence of Ga20 or (GaO) + species during reduction. Moreover, given the observation of H2 consumption in TPR and the data of previous studies [4,6,8,10,20-23,25,26] the former assignment is more likely, and provides in-situ evidence for the Ga20 reduction intermediate proposed by Price and Kanazirev [8] as shown below. Southward et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 135 (1996) 177-191 or overall Ga203+2H+Z-+2H2 ~ 2Ga+Z +3H20 (1 +2) This assignment is tentative since all results presented have not been processed using KM (Kubelka-Munk) or KK (Kramers-Kroenig) transformation [33]. Such methods would reduce the specular reflective effect which dominates the observed signal. However, as stated previously, given the low S/N ratio of the spectra, the protocol employed (co-addition of 250 scans), the low contribution of lattice vibration observed for both Ga203 and all supported variants, and the selec- tive appearance of the band during reduction cycles, it appears the observed band is a true phenomenon. The comparison of GaBM and GaBMP, also reflect previous findings regarding the use of the alkane feed as a reductant [ 2-4,13 ]. However, it is also apparent that the use of propane is not as selective in the activation of the Ga203 as H:. In this case the activation of the gallium may occur due to the dehydrogenation of the alkane by the gallium as previously reported [4,13,31], leading to the formation of the suboxide. If so, then based upon kinetic studies which have shown that competitive adsorption between H2 and propane occurs, with the former inhibiting reaction [ 11 ], this indicates the reaction of the propane is slower than with H2. Moreover, due to the accompanying aromatization reactions, the concentration of propane will be reduced at the catalyst surface, also limiting the reduction efficiency. Alternatively, it may not be merely propane which reduces the gallium oxide, but the H2 produced as a reaction by-product. If so, then reduction will only proceed as determined by the surface partial pressure of H2 by-product, which will again be less efficient than the process occurring in the pure hydrogen case. 5. Conclusions The activation of gallium oxide based aromatization catalysts is achieved by the reduction of the Ga203. This leads to the formation of Ga20 which migrates into the zeolite pores to react with BrOnsted acid sites. Both H2 and propane can fulfil the role of reductant, with reduction being possible upon non-zeolitic supports, providing they possess the required Br0nsted acidity. An in-situ diffuse reflectance IR fourier transform spectroscopy study of the reduction/activation of Ga/H-ZSM-5 and variants thereof has been performed. These studies have shown a synergy between acidic supports (zeolitic and non-zeolitic) and Ga2O3, which leads to the reduction of the latter in either a H2 or propane stream, as evidenced by the loss in intensity of the vGaO band. No reduction of Ga2O3 was observed when it was unsupported or supported upon non-acidic supports. In all cases the reduction process was accompanied by loss of Brønsted acid groups due to reaction between the acidic site and gallium suboxide. Moreover, the appearance of a strong sharp band coincident with the known frequency of the vGaO band was also recorded and is presumed to indicate the presence of Ga2O. Reduction of Ga/H-ZSM-5 using propane as a reductant was accompanied by side reactions and coke deposition and appeared to be a less effective means of activating the catalyst.
